tagline: 70 miles. 10,000+ feet. Where gravel meets high-altitude suffering.

course.terrain_type: Mixed surface climbing with extended descents
course.terrain_surface: Gravel roads, paved climbs, technical mountain descents
course.signature_challenge: The altitude. 10,000+ feet average means your power is down 10-15%. Plan accordingly.
course.character: Relentless vertical. You climb for 35 miles, then descend for 35 miles. Simple math, brutal execution.

suffering_zones.label: Col Summit Approach
suffering_zones.desc: The climbing starts getting real. Thin air starts biting.

suffering_zones.label: Eagle Point Summit
suffering_zones.desc: 11,500 feet. The highest point. You're either adapted or suffering.

suffering_zones.label: Technical Descent
suffering_zones.desc: Tired legs, loose gravel, 30 mph. Focus or crash.

course.climate_description: July at 10,000+ feet means intense sun, thin air, and afternoon thunderstorms

biased_opinion.summary: Crusher is what happens when you take a mountain stage of the Tour and add gravel. It's not for everyone—flat-landers and non-climbers will suffer disproportionately. But if you love vertical and want to test yourself against thin air, this is your race.

logistics.parking: Start area parking is manageable. Arrive 60+ minutes early for setup.

searchable_text: Crusher in the Tushar 70 miles. 10,000+ feet. Where gravel meets high-altitude suffering. Relentless vertical. You climb for 35 miles, then descend for 35 miles. Simple math, brutal execution. The altitude. 10,000+ feet average means your power is down 10-15%. Plan accordingly. 11,500 ft summit Extended paved climbs Steep gravel descents Exposed ridgelines Beaver, Utah Beaver County High-altitude alpine Mixed surface climbing with extended descents
